executive_summary: The Clothing Alteration Services industry has grown in line with overall economic improvement over the majority of the five years to 2021. Broader macroeconomic conditions relevant to this industry have improved significantly during the period, with per capita disposable income expected to increase an annualized 3.0% during the period. Unfortunately for industry operators, demand for clothing alteration services was progressively offset by unfavorable shifts in consumer preferences and mounting competition from other industries that provide identical services, both of which have hampered industry performance during the latter half of the five-year period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Economic conditions broadly strengthened over the majority of the five years to 2021
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With rising disposable income levels and economic activity in full swing, consumers felt comfortable spending on discretionary products, such as clothing.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand for industry services was dampened by unfavorable shifts in consumer preferences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Unfavorable shifts in consumer preferences and mounting competition from other industries that provide identical services have hampered industry performance during the five-year period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: 2020 was an extremely tough year due to COVID-19 pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The global pandemic has forced many operators to close in compliance with social distancing protocols for the foreseeable future.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rebounding macroeconomic trends will translate into renewed demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rebounding macroeconomic trends, such as improving employment levels and increasing disposable income, will translate into renewed demand for industry services as the COVID-19 pandemic passes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mounting competition from outside industries will continue to hurt operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Mounting competition from outside industries and the prevalent consumer preference toward replacing damaged or worn-out garments with new ones, rather than repairing them, will continue to hurt industry operators.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry revenue is forecast to rise at an annualized rate of 1.6%
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: IBISWorld forecasts industry revenue to rise at an annualized rate of 1.6% to $1.9 billion over the five years to 2026.

industry_definition: This industry provides garment repair, tailoring and clothing alteration services, which involve cutting, sewing and reworking clothing items to customers' specifications. The industry also provides care and maintenance to coats made from natural or faux leathers, suede and fur. Industry participants may also provide limited garment cleaning services, although these are technically included in the Dry Cleaners industry.

negative_impact_factors: Low and steady industry assistance level
Low and steady barriers to entry level

key_trends: The global pandemic has forced many operators to close in compliance with social distancing protocols for the foreseeable future
Despite stronger demand for tailoring services, the industry's overall structure has not changed significantly over the past five years
Apparel and department stores that may offer complementary alterations in the store are a source of external competition for this industry
The industry's contribution to the overall economy is projected to increase at an annualized rate of 1.1% over the 10 years to 2026, relatively in line with GDP growth

The key driver for the industry's slowdown has been intense competition from outside industries, particularly the declining Dry Cleaners industry and the mature Men's and Women's Clothing Stores industries
The proliferation of inexpensive, yet high-quality imported clothing has enabled consumers to purchase new clothing more regularly, reducing the need for alteration or repair services

market_segmentation.segment_description: Demand for women over the age of 16 will generate an estimated 53.2% of industry revenue in 2021. Women's apparel dominates the apparel market in general; in 2021, IBISWorld expects Women's Clothing Stores (IBISWorld report 44812) to bring in almost five times the revenue of Men's Clothing Stores (IBISWorld report 44811). Women's apparel also experiences much faster trend turnover than men's apparel. Furthermore, women are more likely to demand higher-margin alteration services for special garments such as fur coats or formal dresses and blouses.

Men over the age of 16 will account for an estimated 35.0% of expenditure on industry services in 2021. Male consumers are a key market for hemming services for dress pants and shirts, waist adjustment, discoloration treatment for leather jackets, and sleeve length alterations for suits.

According to the BLS and IBISWorld estimates, expenditures on apparel services for children aged under 16, which includes purchases made directly by children as well as purchases made by adults on behalf of children, will account for an estimated 11.8% of the industry in 2021.

products_and_services.product_description: Hemming and sleeve-shortening services are expected to account for 28.4% and 12.5% of Clothing Alteration Services industry revenue in 2021, respectively. A hem refers to a specific garment finishing method where the end of a piece of fabric is folded underneath and sewn to prevent unraveling. In clothing alteration, hemming refers to the process of undoing and restitching a hem to lengthen or shorten the piece of clothing.

Sales from waist adjustment services will represent an estimated 10.6% share of industry revenue. Coupled with hemming services, waist adjustments represent the second-most common clothing alteration services that industry participants offer, contributing a combined 51.5% of industry revenue.

This service segment, which mostly includes alteration services for suits, tuxedos, formal dresses, blouses, and sport jackets, is expected to account for 31.5% of the industry. This segment's share of revenue has increased in line with overall declines in unemployment. With more Americans returning to work, demand from consumers who wear professional attire at work has increased.

Repair and maintenance services for specialty garments are expected to account for a 9.0% share of the industry. Specialty garments include outerwear made from natural materials, such as leather jackets or fur coats, as well as delicate garments such as cashmere or wool sweaters and sportswear such as soft-shell or fleece jackets.

Clothing alteration businesses provide a variety of other garment-related services such as zipper repair, mending services, spot stain removal and embroidery. Sales from these miscellaneous services are expected to constitute the remaining 8.0% share of the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for the Clothing Alteration Services industry's services is dependent on economic factors such as the unemployment rate and household income levels, as well as shifts in consumer preferences. Clothing alteration services are used by households across all income levels, although demand from households with incomes above $60,000 has been the key driver for industry performance over the five years to 2021.

While rising disposable income levels and strong economic conditions enable consumers to increase spending on discretionary services such as clothing alteration, they also encourage consumers to spend more on new clothing. When consumers choose to purchase new garments instead of seeking alterations or repair services for ones they already own, demand for industry services falters.

This trend has been driven by imports of inexpensive, yet high-quality garments from countries with relatively lower wage costs. In fact, the United States has lost an estimated 90.0% of its apparel manufacturing jobs over the past 20 years because of high import penetration. Furthermore, imports accounted for 95.0% of domestic demand for all Men's and Boy's clothing categories in 2021.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The Clothing Alteration Services industry only services the domestic market. Since clothing alteration businesses service the day-to-day alteration needs of consumers, companies must be domestically based to provide fast delivery and turnaround times. Therefore, there is no international trade in this industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest concentration of population and industry establishments (30.9%).
The West region accounts for 14.9% of industry establishments.
The Great Lakes region accounts for 14.6% of industry establishments.
The Mid-Atlantic region, which is home to major metropolitan areas like the Northeast corridor from New York City to Washington, DC, houses an estimated 13.5% of all establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Clothing Alteration Services industry has a low level of regulation. Tailors are required to abide by the typical federal regulations regarding fair labor practices and standards and to follow the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration's safety guidelines. Tailors are not required to obtain a state or federal license.

To mitigate the spread of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, federal and state governments enacted regulations regarding business closures and social distancing requirements. Since the industry applies directly to household appliances, industry operators were deemed nonessential; and thus, were required to close their operations until the mandates were lifted. Once reopened, businesses were required to implement safety measures such as mask mandates and social distancing.

basis_points.basis_description: Clothing Alteration Services industry operators compete with one another primarily on the basis of price, business location, breadth of services offered, quality of service, and turnaround time.
The industry primarily contends with competition from dry cleaning establishments and department stores.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Similar to other industries in the personal and household goods repair and maintenance sector, the Clothing Alteration Services industry has a very low market share concentration, with no company expected to account for more than a 1.0% share of the whole industry in 2021.

The industry is dominated by nonemployers, which are establishments owned and operated by only one person or family, and therefore have no other employees. In fact, nonemployers are expected to account for more than 96.8% of all industry participants in 2021.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As with the rest of the repair and maintenance sector, garment repair and alteration remains a labor-intensive process. Consequently, wage costs are expected to constitute the largest expense of industry operators.

Purchases comprise the second-largest expense for industry operators, accounting for an estimated 18.0% of revenue in 2021. This segment's share of revenue has remained relatively steady over the past five years. Key purchases include plastic bags, premade garments, various linens, and other fabrics directly from garment factories, sewing mills, or wholesale distributors. Depending on the range of services offered, operators may also purchase replacement sewing machine needles, detergents, and fabric conditioners (e.g. natural oils for leather or suede).

Depreciation rates are expected to account for a 2.5% share in 2021. The majority of the equipment used by operators needs to be replaced every couple of years, causing depreciation to be a relatively high share of industry revenue.

Marketing is set to account for 1.1% of industry revenue in 2021. The majority of operators are small nonemployers serving a specific geographic area, and as a result, they primarily rely on word-of-mouth advertising.

Rent is set to account for 2.6% of industry revenue. While many operators do lease store fronts in high-traffic areas, increasingly nonemployers are traveling to clients' homes to make at-home alterations.
Utilities are estimated to account for 0.7% and include all necessary costs to keep shops up and running.
Other costs include administrative and insurance expenses. These costs are set to account for the remaining 32.6% of industry revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital investments are primarily made on sewing and hemming equipment, presses, clothing irons, sorting bins, and computers to track orders and manage sales. Larger alteration shops may also purchase professional pressing equipment, which are used to finalize and remove wrinkles from newly tailored garments.

Despite a modest increase in the use of automated machinery in recent years, the actual garment repair and alteration process remains a specialized, very labor-intensive profession where most services are conducted by hand.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Over the five years to 2021, industry sales are expected to increase as much as 10.7% in 2019 and decreased as much as 22.9% in 2020. This industry is typically characterized by low volatility because of its high market penetration rate across all US regions, its highly fragmented nature, and the relatively wide range of services offered that cater to a wide range of consumers.

However, significant losses from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak created high volatility in this industry during the five-year period, and that volatility is anticipated to wane over the five years to 2026.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While the Clothing Alteration Services industry has been vulnerable to much technological disruption, the majority of operators have been able to leverage the new technology. For example, many alteration service companies, especially in major cities, now offer at-home consultations where they visit the client's home and make the necessary adjustments.
Further, among the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak, in-home tailoring increased in popularity as individuals viewed it as a safer way to get their items altered.

FAQs.question: Are your sales reliant on the overall health of the US economy (i.e., consumer spending and per capita disposable income)?
FAQs.answer: Demand for this industry's services is dependent on economic factors such as the unemployment rate and household income levels, as well as shifts in consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging new technology, such as mobile phone applications, to streamline booking and communication with customers?
FAQs.answer: As technology becomes more commonplace, operators are implementing online booking systems and accounts in order to more efficiently communicate with customers.

FAQs.question: Does your company work with any trade associations?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with trade associations, such as the Customer Tailors and Designers Association, to stay up to date with any trends or changes affecting the industry.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Clothing alteration companies are subject to little regulation; however, Dry Cleaners are subject to a higher level of environmental regulations. Its compliance may marginally impact some of this industry's tailors, especially in situations where tailors share a workspace with dry cleaners.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average industry profit margins have increased recently as a result of increased demand for high priced items, such as suede and leather jackets.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company have to replace its equipment?
FAQs.answer: Depending on the type of sewing machine, the lifespan can range from five to 25 years. Clothing alteration operators must ensure that their machines are working and efficient in order to retain customers, as well as attract new consumers.

FAQs.question: Are you located in a densely populated area? How close are you to your nearest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Accessibility to consumers is the most important factor for the success of any participants in the industry since the consumers are widely spread geographically.

FAQs.question: Are you a family owned and operated business? How do you attract and retain skilled workers? Do you offer ongoing training for your employees?
FAQs.answer: The industry is labor-intensive and the industry's needs for skilled labor are ever increasing.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good reputation? How much of your business comes from word-of-mouth recommendations? How do you retain your current client base?
FAQs.answer: Word of mouth has been the most effective advertising method in the industry, and it is anticipated that it will keep its vital importance in the foreseeable future.

FAQs.question: Do you find revenue trends are in line with changes in competition? What services do customers tend to buy when competition is high? When it is low?
FAQs.answer: Dry-cleaning establishments are adding tailoring services to their offerings in an effort to expand their customer reach and generate more revenue. Likewise, department stores often provide tailoring when customers purchase apparel from the store as an added incentive to shop there.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you create demand when disposable income levels are low?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have more spending cash, they are more likely to take their garments to the tailor to enhance the fit. When incomes are low, consumers often forgo altering apparel unless it is absolutely necessary.

FAQs.question: Do you specialize in alterations to high-quality or delicate garments? How do you appeal to higher-earning consumers?
FAQs.answer: Households earning more than $100,000 are more likely to choose higher-margin alteration services. These consumers typically purchase specialty garments that require care and maintenance more frequently than standard garments do, which boosts demand for industry.
